The lower court misdirected itself. The law that protected the Interpol document was a set of two UK legislations (Freedom of Information Act 2000 and the Data Protection Act 1998) which have no effect what so ever in Malawi as they are not statutes of general application. Only statutes which were in force in England on the eleventh day of August, 1902 and any such Acts as have been applied to or are from time to time in force in Malawi are statute of general application in Malawi.

The applicant is appearing in the Court below charged with Uttering Seditious Words contrary to section 51 (l)(a)(b) as read with section 50(1 of the Penal

Code. Clearly there are problems with the hearing of the matter. The applicant feels that his right to a fair trial as guaranteed under our Constitution is being eroded. There are in his view problems with disclosures, witnesses and the charges preferred against him. He therefore approached this court asking it to review the proceedings and give whatever directions it thought fit for the future conduct of the matter. We gave such directions ex tempore on May 7, 2010. This is the written version thereof.

JURISDICTON The first question we have to set straight before going into other substantive issues raised by the applicant is whether the application is properly before this court. As we understand the law, there is no appeal from the subordinate court to the superior benches unless on a final decision of the former. We say this to emphasize the point that this matter in so far as we are concerned should not be and is not an appeal against whatever has happened in the trial court. Having said that I think we should also emphasize the point that under the Courts Act [section 26] and also the Criminal Procedure and Evidence Code [CP&EC] the High Court has supervisory powers over subordinate courts. This application therefore was made and received pursuant to those supervisory powers as opposed to being an appeal as properly understood. Whatever we are going to say and do will be in our supervisory capacity over criminal trials in subordinate courts. Having said that, I think we should also reiterate that sitting in this supervisory capacity we should guard against doing that which courts normally do on appeal namely to reverse or review decisions made by the trial courts. If we did that, we would be doing exactly what we have said we should not do that is treating this matter, via the back door, as an appeal when it is not.

Impartiality And Independence Section 42(2)(f) of our Constitution entitled an accused to trial only before an impartial and independent court. Courts should, to borrow words from elsewhere, not only be impartial and independent they should be seen to be such. It is important therefore that the courts as much as possible keep their distance from the proceedings before them. We have above alluded to the tendency in this jurisdiction to treat criminal prosecutions as some kind of war. And if it is war which parties want prosecutions to be the courts can only be arbitrators or referees. Unlike the modern football referee this court thinks courts should keep some distance between them and the matter they are hearing. If they do not there is always the danger that the dust and noise generated by war will get into its ears and eyes and affect whatever decision it

Summoning of Witnesses Section 195 of the CP&EC empowers any police officer of or above the rank of Assistant Superintendent or any magistrate dealing with a case, or the High Court Registrar to issue a summons to any person requiring his attendance before the court as a witness. If the witness fails without good excuse to appear in answer to such summons the court may issue a warrant for his arrest.

Under section 197 of the CPEtEC a court is also allowed to issue a warrant for the arrest of a witness if satisfied by evidence on oath that such witness will not attend unless compelled to do so. Under section 202 of the CPEtEC a witness other than the accused who inter alia refuses to be sworn or to answer any question put to him may be treated as a refractory witness. The court is empowered as result thereof to commit such witness to prison for a period of up to eight days. Under section 230 of the CPEtEC the court may allow the prosecution on application to treat its own witness as a hostile witness and put to him questions normally put in cross-examination.

Summoning Of Witnesses The law is clear and we have cited it above. A witness duly summoned should attend court on the appointed day without fail. If he fails without good cause the court may issue a warrant for such a witness' arrest. It is important however to differentiate between a witness' attendance and a witness' testimony. Where a witness is duly summoned and fails to attend for no good reason he may be arrested. The arrest is to secure the witness' attendance at court. Not to force him to testify. This sanction is applied because failure for no good reason to comply with a court order is tantamount to contempt. Where however a witness attends court but fails to testify the sanction is not to arrest. It is to resort to sections 202 or 230 under which a witness can within certain specifications be declared either a refractory or hostile witnesses. The sanctions under sections 195, 202 and 230 should be handled with great care though. Firstly we doubt whether a witness who must be forced to testify is of any use to the prosecution. Secondly there are strict conditions that must be met before the sanctions can apply. One of them is that the witness must be served personally. Another is that the witness must have no good excuse for either failing to attend court or refusing to be sworn in or to testify. It is our

Costs/Expenses We have no doubt that amendments may result in the resummoning of witnesses, recommencement of proceedings or the reinstructing of counsel. The applicant will be put to extra cost/expense thereby. It is unfair we think that the accused/ applicant should bear this cost/expense when he is not at fault. The State who by their failure to get the prosecution right the first time round should in our view bear the extra cost/ expense necessitated by either a recall of witnesses, a recommencement of proceedings de novo or a If the State decides in this case to amend or bring new charges altogether any costs or expenses incurred by the accused/ applicant in connection therewith shall be borne by the State. For purposes of guidance only we feel obliged to point out that in case of legal representation the Constitution entitles the applicant to counsel of his choice. Unless the applicant's demands are outrageous the State will meet the costs of such service.

column4: Section 346 of the Criminal Procedure and Evidence Code
column7: The Director of Public Prosecution now seeks to appeal against this sentence and learned State Counsel argues that this is permissible under the general rule embodied in sub-section (l) of Section 346 of the Criminal Procedure and Evidence Code (cap 8:01 ).

With respect, I do not agree. Sub-section (3) of the Section makes it clear that the only right of appeal in the Director of Public Prosecutions is against an acquittal. If sub-section (l) were as wide as learned State Counsel contended, then there would have been no necessity for the legislature to enact sub-section (3).

With respect, I do not agree. Sub-section (3) of the Section makes it clear that the only right of appeal in the Director of Public Prosecutions is against an acquittal. If sub-section (l) were as wide as learned State Counsel contended, then there would have been no necessity for the legislature to enact sub-section (3).

With respect, I do not agree. Sub-section (3) of the Section makes it clear that the only right of appeal in the Director of Public Prosecutions is against an acquittal. If sub-section (l) were as wide as learned State Counsel contended, then there would have been no necessity for the legislature to enact sub-section (3).

With respect, I do not agree. Sub-section (3) of the Section makes it clear that the only right of appeal in the Director of Public Prosecutions is against an acquittal. If sub-section (l) were as wide as learned State Counsel contended, then there would have been no necessity for the legislature to enact sub-section (3).

The argument that a Director of Public Prosecutions or the State can not appeal against sentence is merited in so far as the Section 346 (3) of the Code stood as at the I lth day of November, 1971 but has no merit after the amendment was made to the sub-section in 1973 vide Act No. 18 of 1973. The legislature must have noted some mischief in the old sub- section (3) of the Code which it chose to regularise hence the amendment in 1973.

It is thus my considered view that the rights of appeal to the Director of Public Prosecutions under Section 346 (3) are no longer confined to an acquittal but extend also to any other "final judgment" or "order". The only restriction in my view is as to matters or points of "law" and not "fact". It is thus my further considered view that the Director of Public Prosecutions or the State in the present case can appeal against the order requiring the Respondent to pay a fine only without at the same time ordering forfeiture of the currency. And as regards the argument that the State has not offered good reason why it did not appeal within the prescribed period of 10 days of the date of sentencing, it may be worth reproducing the relevant provision under which the application to appeal out of time was made by the Appellant. The relevant provision which is Section 346 of the Code provides as follows:- No appeal to the High Court shall be entertained from any finding, sentence or order unless the appellant shall have given notice in writing to the High Court of his intention to appeal within ten days of the date of the finding, sentence or order appealed against: Provided that:-

The only restriction in my view is as to matters or points of "law" and not "fact". It is thus my further considered view that the Director of Public Prosecutions or the State in the present case can appeal against the order requiring the Respondent to pay a fine only without at the same time ordering forfeiture of the currency. And as regards the argument that the State has not offered good reason why it did not appeal within the prescribed period of 10 days of the date of sentencing, it may be worth reproducing the relevant provision under which the application to appeal out of time was made by the Appellant. The relevant provision which is Section 346 of the Code provides as follows:- No appeal to the High Court shall be entertained from any finding, sentence or order unless the appellant shall have given notice in writing to the High Court of his intention to appeal within ten days of the date of the finding, sentence or order appealed against: Provided that:-
Notwithstanding this section, the High Court may, for good cause, admit an appeal although the periods of limitation prescribed in this section have elapsed.'
Notwithstanding this section, the High Court may, for good cause, admit an appeal although the periods of limitation prescribed in this section have elapsed.'

Upon the perusal of the provisions quoted above It is my considered view that albeit there is a prescribed period of 10 days during which the Notice of Appeal ought to be lodged by an Appellant this Honourable Court has a discretion to allow the Notice of Appeal outside that period if good cause for the delay can be shown. This being the position, the question to be considered in the present case is: 'did the State at the time of the hearing of the for leave to appeal out of time show good cause as is required by Section 349 (4) of the Code.

Put simply, the reason advanced by the State for the failure to file the Notice of Appeal within the prescribed 10 days' period is the State's failure to make a decision on what to do. If I am right in ascertaining the State's position, the question to be resolved is whether or not the reason as ascertained suffices as a "good cause" within the provisions of Section 349 (4) of the Code?

This being the only evidence available this Court equally fails to appreciate how the lower Court arrived at the conclusion that the Appellant authored the said Exhibit. The mere fact that the transaction was concluded with the shareholding on the Exhibit inflated cannot perse be evidence to show that the Appellant was the author of the Exhibit. The simple reason the transaction was concluded, in this Court's view, is the involvement of the Appellant as a senior officer of the company in the processing of the same and not the Appellant's authorship of the Exhibit. For these reasons this Court is inclined to agree with the States' submission that the Appellant's conviction under Section 364 (a) of the Penal Code was not properly grounded. It is thus hereby set aside. The conviction under Section 364 (b) of the Penal Code is however, upheld.

column4: Section 339 and 340 of the Criminal Procedure and Evidence Code
column7: In relation to this ground of Appeal it is the submission of Counsel for the Appellant that as per the evidence of PW8, Mr David Makwala, the Managing Director for Trust Finance, since the Appellant used to discharge his duties with due diligence and that this was the first and only time he was implicated in a criminal offence he ought to have been dealt with in terms of Section 339 and 340 of the Criminal Procedure and Evidence Code which are to the effect that first offenders have to be dealt with leniently when sentencing and that non-custodial sentence should be meted out on them unless there is reason not to do so and that where a custodial sentence is meted out on them the presiding judicial officer has a duty to explain reasons for the sentence.

On their part the State have submitted that it is trite that the maximum sentence is reserved for the worst offenders and that the Appellant being a first offender he deserves leniency though the amount involved is colossal. The State have thus proposed a sentence of 24 months imprisonment with hard labour as appropriate on the first count of theft and that the sentence of 24 months imprisonment with hard labour on the second count ought to be slightly lowered.

column4: Section 42 (2) (e) of the Republic of Malawi Constitution
column7: Reverting to the present Application, there can be no doubt, in my mind, that an Accused person like the Applicant herein has a Constitutional right under Section 42 (2) (e) of the Republic of Malawi Constitution to be released from detention, with or without bail, unless the interests of justice require otherwise. But as is apparent from the said provision the right of an Accused to be released is not absolute but is dependent on the interests of justice. This fact was emphasised by the Malawi Supreme Court of Appeal in the case of DIRECTOR OF PUBLIC PROSECUTIONS V LUNGUZI [1 995) 2MRL 632 at page 635 where their Lordships said:-

"The right to bail has always been known to our law and all that Section 42 (2) (e) does is to give it constitutional force. We would like to emphasise that Section 42 (2) (e) does not give an absolute right to bail. The Courts will always continue to exercise their discretion depending on the circumstances obtaining in each particular case. "

"The right to bail has always been known to our law and all that Section 42 (2) (e) does is to give it constitutional force. We would like to emphasise that Section 42 (2) (e) does not give an absolute right to bail. The Courts will always continue to exercise their discretion depending on the circumstances obtaining in each particular case. "

Counsel cited the case of Rep v Lawrence 9 MLR 315 in support of his arguments. It was also his arguments that while the would in the Lawrence case was exposed, in the present case the extent of the wound was not established and that it was only a few satures. It was also Counsel's submission that since the Appellant is a first offender as per the lower Court's finding at page 47 of the Court Record the lower Court ought to have suspended the sentence imposed on the Appellant in terms of Sections 339 and 340 of the Criminal Procedure and Evidence Code. It was thus Counsel's prayer that the sentence imposed on the Appellant be suspended and that an Order for the immediate release of the Appellant be made by this Court.

column4: Sections 339 and 340 of the Criminal Procedure and Evidence Code
column7: After hearing the submissions made by Counsel herein I reduced the sentence of 12 months imprisonment with hard labour to 9 months and suspended the operation of the same in terms of Sections 339 and 340 of the Criminal Procedure and Evidence Code on the following conditions:- a) that the Appellant does not commit a similar offence for a period of 2 years from the date of her conviction by the lower Court; and b) that the Appellant pays a sum of K 10,000.00 to the complainant as compensation.

I have considered the submissions made by both Counsel and I wish to commend them for their valued submissions. I have noted the distinction Counsel for the State has drawn between the facts of the present case from those in the case of Chikwekwe v Republic Criminal Appeal No. 76 of 2005 where Chipeta J, reduced the sentence of 18 months Imposed by the lower court to 9 months on the grounds that while in the Chikwekwe case there was no evidence of the wound having been sutured, there was evidence that the wound had been sutured in the present case. I understand Counsel as arguing that this meant that the wound in the present case was more serious than in the Chikwekwe case and that as such the Appellant in this case deserved a stiffer sentence than the Appellant in the Chikwekwe case. While I entirely agree with Counsel for the State in her argument it is to be appreciated that the Appellant in the Chikwekwe case had a previous record of conviction for the offence of Assault occasioning actual bodily harm contrary to Section 254 of the Penal Code and yet the Appellant in the present case has no record of a previous conviction whatsoever. This fact would in my view militate in favour in reducing the sentence against the Appellant in this case. To maintain a sentence of 12 months imprisonment with hard labour for a first offender when an offender with a previous conviction was able to go away with only a 9 months' sentence for a similar offence would in my considered view not be fair. I thus reduced the 12 months' sentence to 9 months. The sentence is to take effect from the date of the conviction by the lower court.

In the case of The Republic vs Hassan Selemani Confirmation case No. 418 cf 2008, a 30 month sentence was enhanced to 42 months imprisonment with hard labour although the offender pleaded guilty, was young and the case of The Republic vs Kabichi Confirmation case No. 294 of 1994, the court stated that it must never be thought that public interest is better served by longer sentences. It is sometimes served by shorter sentences. This is so for first and young offenders for whom a short stint in prison might be all that has to be done for them to learn a lesson for such sterner sentences may only result.

column7: As regards the charge the third accused was answering the State agrees that there was no amendment to the charge sheet to include the third accused and it is not clear what charge the third accused answered to until the end. The State rightly observed that it is mandatory under section 83 of the Criminal Procedure and Evidence Code that prosecution can only be instituted by drawing up a formal charge. Although S.84 of the Criminal Procedure and Evidence Code provides that proceedings shall not be nullified by a defect in the charge sheet, to have no charge sheet at all would occasion a failure of justice and would be fatal to any conviction.

column4: Section 187(1) of the Criminal Procedure and Evidence Code
column7: "Under Section 187(1) of the Criminal Procedure and Evidence Code and from countless decided cases, including Woolmington v DPP as well as from learned authors of texts on Criminal Procedure and Evidence, it is clearly cardinal that in general the legal burden to prove the guilt of the accused rests with and never leaves the prosecution

throughout a case, and that the standard of proof to be attained does not get lower than that of beyond reasonable doubt. Further, under our Constitution Section 42(2)(f)(iii) every person accused ofa crime is presumed innocent and does not bear any duty in the least to prove such innocence...[A]n accused need do no more than raise, if he opts to fight the allegation against him, some reasonable doubt about his guilt. It is in fact not even obligatory for him to give any evidence in defence. Thus even doubts solely arising from prosecution evidence itself are sufficient to free him from the yoke of the charges, even without him uttering a word, let alone doubts arising from defence testimony... It is clearly the law that reasonable doubts in a criminal case, whether arising from the prosecution evidence, or from the defence, or from both sides, must be resolved in favour of the accused.

column4: section 176 of the Criminal Procedure and Evidence Code
column7: Evidence of a confession is admissible under section 176 of the Criminal Procedure and Evidence Code. This is so notwithstanding any objection on the part of the accused either that the same was not made by him or if made by him that the same was not freely and voluntarily made and without having been unduly influenced to make it and the court may take the confession into account if the court is satisfied beyond reasonable doubt that the confession was made by the accused and that its contents are materially true. On the other hand if the court is not so satisfied the court is required to give no weight whatsoever to such a confession. In the case of Useni and others v R 1964-1966 ALR Mal. 250 it was held that a free and voluntary confession made by the accused to any person at any time or place is admissible against him as the highest proof of guilt as such confession is presumed to be true and if the confession is later retracted it is open to the court to disbelieve the retraction. It was also held in that case that an admissible confession does not require corroboration and an accused may be convicted on his confession alone. Corroboration of a confession is required as a matter of law when and if the accused, subsequently retracts it: Chiphaka v Republic 1971-72 ALR Mal 214; Republic v Hara [1993]

The case was then adjourned for hearing. However, when the case came up for hearing before me on the 13th day of January, 2010 his Counsel, Mr. M'mame of Legal Aid Department, advised the Court that his client had decided to change his plea. I thus ordered the accused to take fresh plea. And after the statement of the offence and the particulars thereof had been read out to him, the accused admitted that he understood and admitted the charge. The accused also admitted the facts as narrated by State Counsel as correct. I thus convicted the accused of the offence of Manslaughter contrary to Section 208 of the Penal Code on his own plea of guilty and reserved the sentence to be matted on him to a date to be fixed.

The Malawi Supreme Court of Appeal in the case of Director of Public Prosecutions v Lunauzi [1 995] 2 MLR 632 at pp 635 to 636 commenting on the right to bail provided for by Section 42 (2) (e) of the Constitution said:-

"The right to bail has always been known to our law and all that Section 42 (2) (e) does is to give it constitutional force. We would like to emphasize that Section 42 (2) (e) does not give an absolute right to bail. The Court will continue to exercise their discretion depending on the circumstances obtaining in each particular case. While it is true that the High Court can, in its discretion, grant bail in any case we feel the discretion should be exercised with extreme caution and care in the most serious offences. There are fundamental principles of universal application in common law jurisdictions which our courts must not lose sight of. They are principles which must always be to the forefront of any court considering an application for bail. It must, of course, not be withheld merely as a punishment. The requirements as to bail are intended to secure the attendance of the prisoner at his or her trial. The Applicant in the present case is answering a charge of murder contrary to Section 209 of the Penal Code. The maximum punishment prescribed for this offence under Section 210 of the said Code is death. This is thus no doubt, a very serious offence. It is thus likely that the Applicant if released on bail may attempt to evade his trial or even attempt to intimidate his wife who is one of the key witnesses in this case. For these reasons I do not think that it would be in the interest of justice that the Applicant be released on I am however, mindful of the fact that special circumstances militating in favour of the release of the Applicant on bail do exist in this case in that the Applicant has remained in custody for a period of more than 12 months but it remains my fortified view that the interests of justice require that the Applicant be remanded in custody pending his trial. However, to avoid any further undue delay in the determination of this case I order that arrangements be made by the State to bring the Applicant to court for trial within the next 3 months from the date hereof failing which the Applicant is at liberty to re-apply to this Court for bail.

Although the learned judge in that case was not dealing with an application for bail pending an appeal, but an order for stay pending an appeal, he nevertheless made an illuminating statement on the point under consideration. What had happened in that case was that the applicant was charged in the First Grade Magistrate's Court at Thyolo, with causing death by dangerous driving contrary to Section 123(4) of the Road Traffic Act. He was convicted and sentenced to pay a fine of MK160.00 and was disqualified from driving for four years. He applied to the magistrate for an order staying the operation of the order of disqualification pending the determination of his appeal against conviction and sentence. The application was refused on the ground that staying the order was not mandatory. He subsequently made a similar application to the High Court. It was submitted on his behalf that (a) the power to stay the order of disqualification was discretionary and it did not appear that the magistrate had exercised the discretion judicially (b) for 1 1 months since the making of the order the applicant had been driving without committing any further offence (c) he had previously been driving for nine years without conviction. In view of (b) and (c) it was argued that he was not a menance on the roads and should be permitted to drive pending the determination of the appeal. The state opposed the application in principle on the ground that the applicant had not shown that any exceptional and unusual circumstances of hardship would arise if the order were put into effect immediately. The court held that the operation of an order of disqualification from driving will only be stayed pending an appeal if exceptional and unusual circumstances of hardship to the applicant are shown. Such circumstances may be the court's belief that the appeal will succeed in its entirety and the likelihood that it cannot be disposed of within a reasonably short time. In the case of Amon Zgambo V Rep , the Supreme Court stated the law, as followers per Banda, C.J. as he then was:

"The right to bail as enshrined in the Malawi Constitution provides that every person arrested for or accused of the commission of an offence shall among other rights which he or she has as a detained person have, the right to be released from detention with or without bail unless the interests of justice require otherwise. column4: Section 151 of the Criminal Procedure and Evidence Code
column7: However, it should also be borne in mind that justice is a double edged sword and that when it comes to criminal matters, justice must not only seen to be done but that it must be done. This is especially in view of the fact that an accused person has a right to a fair trial, which actually denotes that he should be given an opportunity to properly defend himself against the charges that have been brought against him. The question thus becomes was the appellant given an opportunity to defend himself against the charge that he corruptly solicited a bribe in order to grant Judith Muloti and her husband bail? We think not, because the right to a fair trial also requires that an accused should be informed, with sufficient particularity [emphasis mine] of the charge against him. In this instance we do not think that there was sufficient particularity since there was a misconstruction in the particulars of the offence. Indeed unless and until the court the court decides under Section 151 of the Criminal Procedure and Evidence Code that the charge should be amended and then call upon the accused to take a fresh plea on the amended or altered charge, it is bound to proceed with the charge as proffered. This is especially critical in cases where the intention of the accused is key in arriving at a conviction. This is of course not saying that it would be right for a police officer to solicit a bribe so as to forego and investigation into an allegation. All I am stating in this case is

Now in order to resolve this issue I must note that whilst as there was a misconstruction in the charge, the facts that were presented before the court were that the appellant asked Judith Muloti's husband for some money so that he can release the latter on bail. However, as earlier noted, and it is well settled, that police bail is supposed to be free such that if a police officer would request money from a suspect so that the suspect should be released on bail, then it can be safely be assumed that the said officer made such a request so that he can use the money for his own benefit and thus the police officer would be guilty of Official Corruption under Section 90(a) of the Penal Code. In this regard therefore the finding of the lower court cannot be faulted. This is also in view of the fact that the Bail Guidelines for the Police do clearly provide that:

every indication that with such malicious intentions, the Appellant did indeed solicit money from Judith Muloti's husband so that he could release him on bail. In this regard, I did note from the record of the lower court that when he was asked about the money, the appellant seemed to admit that he had indeed collected money from the complainant's husband but he was not sure that he had given it back. Indeed whilst it is allowed for police officers to remove from the person of a suspect some personal effects including money, these are supposed to be properly recorded so that when the person is released from custody they should be given back. Thus surely if the appellant had indeed taken money from the complainant for safekeeping, he should have kept a record of the same but most importantly he should have been able to remember. In the final analysis, then it is observed that much as the finding on the lower court was not based on the charge as proffered. The finding was based on the evidence that was adduced before the lower court and the law. Further, it is noted that the appellant had the opportunity to hear such evidence and then enter his defence. Indeed much as it is not clear that as to whether the Appellant was the most senior police officer at Mtambanyama Police Unit or not, it is quite clear that he was the only officer on duty at the time. In this regard, the charging of Judith Muloti and her husband for the offences of assault fell within his duties. Further, it was also within his duties to release the Appellants unconditionally when it became clear that the complainants of the assault charge were not going to pursue the case any further. Thus the fact that the Appellant did ask for money in order to release Judith Muloti's husband would make him guilty of the charge of official corruption contrary to Section 90(a) of the Penal Code. In this regard, I must then state that the lower court was not wrong in arriving at the decision that it did. It is therefore with these views in mind that I would conclude that there was no miscarriage of justice which was occasioned in the trial of the Appellant in the lower court which would necessitate that I should order a new trial on the charge of official corruption. It is thus in this regard that I will proceed to confirm that conviction on the first count of official corruption and dismiss the appeal against the same. Having dismissed the appeal against the conviction on the charge of official corruption, I must now address the issue of the sentence. Indeed it is only in very rare and exceptional circumstances where someone who has been found guilty of a felony is considered for a suspended sentence, this is

regardless of whether they are a first offender and that there are other mitigating circumstances. In this case in particular, the appellant was a police officer and thus he was in a position of authority. He abused that authority in the most grievous manner by demanding money when he did not have the authority or justification to do so. As noted on several occasions above, there was no case on which he could have legally held Judith Muloti and her husband in custody. Indeed the holding them in custody, in my view, was done out of pure malice and as it turned out, very sinister intentions. Of course I noted from the sentence that was imposed by the lower court that the Appellant was sentenced to 144 months Imprisonment with Hard Labour, which happens to be the maximum sentence provided for under Section 90(a) of the Penal Code. In this regard, the usual question that arises is whether the Appellant is the worst type of offender to have committed the offence of official corruption under Section 90(a) of the Penal Code? Of course considering that the Appellant did not only solicit a bribe but was also guilty of the offence of Rape, the temptation to conclude that he is the worst type of offender is indeed high.

Introduction The accused in this matter Luka Banda from Chidiwa Village, T/A Chindi, Mzimba District was charged with the offence of manslaughter contrary to section 208 of the Penal Code (Cap 7:01) of the Laws of Malawi. He pleaded not guilty to the charge. The particulars as alleged by the State are that the accused on or about the 4th September, 2008 at Chidiwa Village unlawfully caused the death of Daniel

Prima facie Case At the close of the prosecution's case both the State and Defence had agreed that the court should proceed to make a ruling without formal submission. It is trite law that at the close of the prosecution case the court must rule whether a prima facie has been made out or not. This procedure came about in view of section 294(2) Criminal Procedure & Evidence Code which empowers a Minister to direct that some class of cases be tried by the High Court without a jury. In the absence of a jury the court shall with any necessary modifications follow the procedure set out in Part VII and used in subordinate court.

Offence of Manslaughter The offence charged is under section 208 of the Penal Code. "Any person who by an unlawfu/ act or omission causes the death of another person sha// be guilty of the felony termed 'manslaughter'.

For the offence to stand the State must prove that there was an unlawful act or omission. An unlawful act must be distinguished from acts emanating from In a charge of manslaughter the state of mind of the malice aforethought. accused must lack premeditation or prior planning which is the mens rea for murder. Under section 208 of the Penal Code there must be death which is

Causing Death Daniel Mwawa did not die immediately on the spot. He was taken home. The following day he was taken to Euthini Hospital where he was given some medication. Things did not improve. He was taken to Mzimba District Hospital and finally to Mzuzu Central Hospital where he succumbed to his injuries and died. Under section 215 of the Penal Code a person is deemed to have caused the death of another person although his act is not the immediate or not the sole cause of death in any of the following cases —

Our deceased did not die on the spot. He was taken to three hospitals before he died. As per the definition of causing death, Dan Mwawa's circumstances must fall within the definition in section 215 of the Penal Code, although it is not clear what really happened at the hospital for him to die. However postmortem reports shows severe head injuries as the cause of death.

Although the accused in a manslaughter charge must lack the mens rea for murder, the state must prove that he had the requisite mens rea necessary to commit the unlawful act which causes the death. As stated earlier on the unlawful act must constitute a criminal offence in its own right. The act must be capable of standing alone as a criminal charge before it causes the death. This therefore means that torts within the meaning in civil law would not constitute an unlawful act within the meaning in section 208 of Penal Code.

Section 42 (2) (e) of the constitution of the Republic of Malawi gives a right to every arrested person, inter alia, to be released from detention, with or without bail, unless the interests of justice require otherwise. And it is trite law that the burden of showing that it would not be in the interest of justice that the accused person be granted bail lies on the State. See FADWECK MVAHE V THE REPUBLIC MSCA Criminal Appeal No. 25 of 2005.

The accused person Peter Missi stands charged with murder contrary to section 209 of the Penal Code. The particulars are that the accused person on or about the 4th day of September, 2009 at Ngonja village in the district of Dowa with malice aforethought caused the death of Atanazio Mtengaponji. He pleaded not guilty to the charge.

The accused person exercised his right under the Constitution to remain silent%ut he called one eye witness in his defence. Although there were some disparities between the evidence of the two eye witnesses, being Pw3
Section209 of the Penal Code under which the accused is charged provides that:

of departure of PW 1 from the scene the deceased again grabbed for the accused. The deceased is not here to say why they did it but it would be a matter in connection with the attack that the accused had done on Pwl. There can be no other reasonable explanation. Little did the deceased realize that he was dealing with an already charged and uncompromising accused. Although the two went down together, it was the accused who sat on top of deceased and kicked him repeatedly in the abdomen. I find that the accused had intended to cause grievous bodily harm on the deceased by repeatedly kicking him. That intention to cause grievious bodily harm -falls within the definition of malice aforethought on contained in Section 212 of the Penal Code. Indeed I am also satisfied beyond reasonable doubt that the accused person knew that his act of kicking the deceased repeatedly would probably cause death or grievous harm on the deceased. Malice aforethought is amply established in this case. I am also satisfied beyond reasonable doubt that the repeated kicking of the deceased by the accused in all circumstances was an unlawful act. I find this as a fact. I find that all the elements of the offence of murder have been proved beyond reasonable doubt.

According to the Affidavit in support of the Application the Applicant was on the 9th day of April, 2010 called to go to Chiradzulu Police Station. And that when he got to the said station he was told by the officers threat that they had received instructions from their Regional Officer to arrest him and that the Regional Officers would come to tell him the reasons for his arrest. After one week of being kept in suspense the Applicant asked the Police Officers to tell him the reason for his arrest when he was told that he was being suspected to have murdered Mr Namithanga who had been killed two days before his arrest. The Applicant was later cautioned and charged with the offence of murder which he denied. He has since been kept in custody, first at Chiradzulu Prison and later transferred to Chichiri Prison where he was up to the date of this Application.

column4: Section 42 (2) (e) of the Republic of Malawi Constitution
column7: The present Application is said to have been made pursuant to Section 42 (2) (e) of the Republic of Malawi Constitution which provides as follows:-

"The right to bail has always been known to our Law and all that Section 42 (2)(e) does is to give it constitutional force. We would like to emphasize that Section 42(2)(e) does not give an absolute right to bail. The courts will always continue to exercise their discretion depending on the circumstances obtaining in each particular case. "

"The right to bail has always been known to our Law and all that Section 42 (2)(e) does is to give it constitutional force. We would like to emphasize that Section 42(2)(e) does not give an absolute right to bail. The courts will always continue to exercise their discretion depending on the circumstances obtaining in each particular case. "

Indeed if the Applicant had not been cautioned and charged as per Counsel's submission the Applicant would not have proceeded with an Application under Section 42(2)(e) of the Constitution of the Republic of Malawi. It is thus my strong conviction that the Applicant has been cautioned and charged with the offence of murder but has denied the same.

column4: Section 42 (2) (e) of the Republic of Malawi Constitution
column7: There is no doubt in my mind that the Applicant in this case has a constitutional right under Section 42 (2) (e) of the Republic of Malawi Constitution to be released from custody with or without bail unless the interests of justice require otherwise. And according to the decision of the Malawi Supreme Court of Appeal in the cases of FADWECK MVAHE V THE REPUBLIC MSCA Criminal Appeal No. 25 of 2005, RICHARD CHIGEZA V THE REPUBLIC MSCA Criminal Appeal No. 26 of 2005 and ROY MANGAME V THE REPUBLIC MSCA Criminal Appeal No. 27 of 2005 the approach which the Courts when determining whether or not to grant bail to the Accused person ought to take seems now settled. Their Lordships at page 22 of their judgment said:

Even reading through the Affidavit in support of the Application one would be left in no doubt that there are a number of murder and robbery charges in respect of which the Applicant is implicated. I would thus hold that the State has discharged the burden reposed on it for refusing the grant of bail to the Applicant. I however wish to add that by Section 4 (a) of the Bail (Guidelines) Act, 2000, the likelihood that the accused if released on bail, will attempt to evade his or her trial is a principle that a Court is required to take into account in deciding whether or not bail should be granted.

column4: Section 165 of the Criminal Procedure and Evidence Code
column7: I have carefully perused Section 165 of the Criminal Procedure and Evidence Code aforesaid and I would agree with State Counsel that it is indeed not obligatory for the succeeding Magistrate to re-summon the witnesses who had given evidence before his predecessor. In my judgment the succeeding Magistrate becomes obligated to re-summon the witnesses only if requested to do so by the accused person. However, much as the succeeding Magistrate is not obliged as stated earlier in this judgment the practice of a succeeding Magistrate proceeding with the trial as if he/she had himself/herself heard the evidence of the witnesses was discouraged by EmeiUIU J in R v Kassema (1964-66) 3 ALR (Mal) at page 474 when he said:-

"In my judgment it is a proper section to use when only formal evidence or evidence of non-controversial matters is given. But when disputed facts are in issue care should be taken either to recall the witnesses or to give the accused person an opportunity to have them recalled for This will give the succeeding cross-examination. Magistrate an opportunity to watch their demeanour in the witness-box and generally to assess the weight to be attached to their evidence, a very necessary advantage

column4: Section 165 of the Criminal Procedure and Evidence Code
column7: In the circumstances I agree with Counsel for the Appellant that it was wrong for the Learned Magistrate to proceed as she did in this case. She ought to have taken cognisance of the provision of Section 165 of the Criminal Procedure and Evidence Code, aforesaid, before proceeding to act on the evidence on the Record. However, in my judgment the decision whether or not this Court should set aside the conviction metted on the Appellant very much depends on whether the Appellant was materially prejudiced by the succeeding Magistrate's failure to re-summon the witnesses or to inform the Appellant of his right to re-summon the witnesses. Having perused the Record of the proceedings in the lower court very carefully I am of the considered view that the Appellant was not materially prejudiced by such a failure. The conviction of the Appellant in the lower Court having been grounded on the evidence of PW2 and PW3 which evidence the Appellant failed to controvert by failing to cross-examine the said witnesses the re-summoning of the witnesses would thus have been a mere waste of time or resources. The fact that the Appellant did not challenge these two witnesses in their averment that the Appellant took away the clothings PW2 was wearing leaving her only with a petticoat and a pant which in turn compelled PW2 to rush to the clothes she had been washing, was sufficient basis for a finding of guilt on him. It is thus my considered view that these grounds of Appeal can not succeed and they are both dismissed.

Counsel for the State on the other hand argued that the definition in the Black's Law Dictionary which Counsel for the Appellant was relying upon was that of "Sexual Assault". It was thus his contention that the said Dictionary has given a very narrow definition of "indecent Assault". Counsel cited the case of Court [1987] 1 ALL ER 120 page 122 as to what was required to be proved for a conviction in an offence of Indecent Assault. He also cited the case of Longdon v DPP 1 997 Crim R. 50. It was his submission that in order to prove an "Indecent Assault" there should be the apprehension in the mind of the victim of the assault and that the same may be without sexual advancement. It was his submission further that the term "Indecent Assault" should be given a wider interpretation and should not be restricted to issues of sexual violence as argued by Counsel for the Appellant. It was also Counsel's submission that for the complainant in this case to rush to the clothes she was washing after she had been left with only undergarments means that it was comprehended in her mind that something had been caused on her part which had been surrounded by acts of indecency. He went on to argue that the prosecution had also proved the Mens Rea of the "Indecent Assault" when they established that the Appellant was reckless in taking off the complainant's garments. It was his submission that both the elements of the offence had been proved and the conviction was thus properly founded.

column4: Section 350(1) of the Criminal Procedure and Evidence Code
column7: The Appellants were dissatisfied with both the conviction and the sentence and they have now appealed to this court to have the conviction quashed and the sentence set aside. The Appellants filed 17 grounds of Appeal. These grounds are set out in a Petition in accordance with Section 350(1) of the Criminal Procedure and Evidence Code and are supported by an affidavit deponed by Bob Chimkango, Legal Practitioner for the Appellants.

The learned Acting Chief Resident Magistrate erred in meting out a custodial sentence to the Appellants when the Appellants were first offender. The learned Acting Chief Magistrate erred in taking into account and basing his decision on an erroneous fact that the Appellants deserved an immediate custodial sentence owing to the fact that the words they spoke were transmitted on radio. The sentencing of the Appellants to 20 months was wrong in law. The learned Acting Chief Resident Magistrate erred in allowing itself to be guided by a decision of a fellow Magistrate's court in sentencing, ignoring the mandatory statutory provisions as well as the standards set by the High Court and the Supreme Court of Appeal. The learned Acting Chief Resident Magistrate erred in imposing a custodial sentence when he convicted the second Appellant for an offence under S.51 of the Penal Code. The learned Acting Chief Resident Magistrate's sentence was wrong in principle and/or manifestly excessive and ought to be set aside.

The Appellants in ground number II have argued that in all circumstances the convictions on proposing violence and uttering seditious words are against the weight of the evidence requiring them to be quashed. They have argued that in criminal case the burden of proving each and every element of the offence lies with the state throughout the trial. The standard required by the criminal law is one beyond reasonable doubt. Woolmington vs. D.P.P. They have argued further that in this case the elements of the offence of proposing violence C/S S.87 (l) (a) of the Penal Code require that the state adduce evidence to the effect that the accused incited or procured people at an assembly to kill or cause injury to a person or community of persons. They have argued that the state failed to show which person was to be killed or to be caused injury to or which community. They have argued that all that was said in court was that the I st accused made a statement likely to cause violence. They have argued further that the spirit of S.87 (l) (a) of the Penal code is that there must be a specific person or a class of person likely to be injured or killed by virtue of the statement made procuring the people assembled. They have argued again that it is not enough just to allege that the accused by their statement was inducing people that the general public cannot be a community of persons.

They have argued again that it is not enough just to allege that the accused by their statement was inducing people that the general public cannot be a community of persons.

On the other hand, the state have argued* that according to S.87 (1) (a) of the Penal Code they were not required to adduce evidence that the accused incited or procured people, it is only required to bring evidence that the accused made a statement or behaved in a particular manner. The statement is made should be calculated or likely to incite or induce and that the use of the word calculated or likely is very significant in that the word means that the Prosecution can either prove the calculation or the likelihood and it satisfies that element. They have argued that while the word calculated points at the intention of the accused, the word likely does not depend on the intention of the accused. The state have argued that in order to show that what the accused did or said was done in a manner calculated to incite or induce, one needs to look at the intention of the accused. On the other hand the offence can be proved by showing that what the accused said or the way he behaved was or is likely to induce or incite. They have argued the words used where they were used, how they were used, the environment, and the people to which that was done and the time. They have argued that there is no needs for change of attitude, that there is no need to prove community of persons or class of persons as general public might also refer to them. They have argued that the words were emotive and had the potential of inducing violence and lawlessness.

The Appellants have argued that all elements of the offence as charged must be proved and they must be proved beyond reasonable doubt. We have noted above that one of the essential elements of the offence under S.87 (I) (a) of the Penal Code is that the Accused must act without

lawful excuse. The argument by the Appellants was that this was during campaign time and as such they were not supposed to be arrested. Section 59 of Parliamentary and Presidential election which has been quoted above provides in the relevant portions that No person shall during or after the period of campaign be subjected to any Criminal Prosecution for statement he made or any opinion he held. I have viewed this provision in the light of S. 87(1) (a) of the Penal code. What the Appellant was charged with is a Criminal Offence and looking at the Parliamentary and Presidential elections Act, this seems inconsistent because the Act is saying "don't prosecute them during the campaign period or even after. The argument by the state however is that the immunity created in S.59 of the Act has been taken away in S.61 (l) of the same Act and that since it has been taken away the Appellants can be subjected to Criminal prosecution. My view is that the intention of the Legislature in enacting Ss.56 — 61 of the Parliamentary and Presidential Elections Act was to entrench the fundamental freedom of expression enshrined in the constitution particularly at Ss. 34 and 35 of the same. I entirely agree with these words. We as courts our duty is to make sure that the Supreme Law of the land is protected and that the laws made under it reflect the principles established by the same supreme law. Indeed there must be consistency between the Penal Code and the Constitution.

I believe that the Legislature did not intend that having created immunity of the contestants in the Parliamentary and President Elections in S.59 could take the immunity away in the succeeding section. This is evident by the fact that S.61 (2) does not create any offence. All it does is to state moral norms which those involved in the campaigning must be aware of. If the intention of Parliamentary or the Legislature was to create an offence in S. 61 (2) of parliamentary and Presidential Elections Act then the subsection would have created one. Surely at the end there should have been the words like "shall be guilty of an offence." Further to this S. 61 (2) of the same Act gives power to the Electoral Commission to prescribe a code of conduct to be complied with by every political party in conducting its campaign in an election.

column4: the Code of conduct and it
column7: It is sad to note that in the court below, the State did not find it necessary to call the Electoral Commission to come and testify to guide and enlighten the court on this point. The court below was therefore denied recourse to the Code of conduct and it would be difficult to speculate as to the contents of the said code of conduct. My view is that it was important especially looking at Ss 59 and 60 of Parliamentary and Presidential Elections Act that electoral Commission should have come to enlighten the court on the position. My conclusion on this point therefore is that this was a campaign period and the Appellants were protected under the law.

The state has argued that the general public can be a community of persons or a person or class of persons. They have relied on S.4 of the Penal Code. The Appellants have contended that a community of persons, or a person or class of persons must be specific and must be known. My reading of the provision S.87 (l) (a) of the Penal Code reveal that elements of the offence of proposing violence require that there should be a person, class of persons and community of persons, class of persons and community of persons to whom harm or physical injury must be intended to be done. Ifthe intention of the legislature was to protect the general public from the alleged offence it could have expressly done so by including the word "public "in the provision. Therefore the prosecution failed to prove their case beyond reasonable doubt on this count.

We have already noted that this was the period of campaign. Elections were two months away. Looking at the extract of the speech of 2nd Appellant as done by the Court below, it can be observed that the 2nd Appellant makes a lot of reference to the date of 19th May, which da was the Election Day. In that extract, the 2nd Appellant makes reference to the Election Day 19 May 10 times. This fact in itself is in consonant with the fact that this was a campaign period and nothing else. The intention here as disclosed was nothing but to persuade the followers and to encourage the supporters to vote for nobody else but Bakili Muluzi during the 19th of May elections. In the case of Chipembere vs. Republic 1961 -1963 ALR Mal. 83 their Lordships held that although seditious intent may by virtue of S.50 (2) of the Penal Code be proved by the presumption that every person is deemed to intent the natural consequences naturally follow from his conduct, the subsection does not shut out "actual intention" and evidence outside the publication of the alleged seditious material whether or not there was seditious intent. And in the case of Useni vs. Republic 1964 — 1966 ALR Mal. 250 Cram J (as he then was) said that:

It can be observed from the authorities above that the circumstances have to be examined very carefully. Sight should not be lost that this was a campaign period and S.59 of Parliamentary and Presidential Elections Act recognizes this fact. This is why "no person shall be subject to any Criminal Prosecution." The words "aka kangwazi" though on the face of it sounds rude was only used as a campaign gimmick and not necessarily meant to demean the President. PW I told the court below that what he saw and heard was nothing but campaign rhetoric.

The Accused, JACKSON KHUMUWA, pleaded guilty to a charge of manslaughter contrary to section 208 of the Penal Code (Cap. 7:01 of the Laws of Malawi) on the 20th day of September, 2010 and was thus convicted on his own plea of guilty. The case was however, adjourned to consider an appropriate sentence to be meted on him after hearing the submissions made by his Counsel, Mr Arthur Nanthulu, the Chief Legal Aid Advocate, in mitigation and the submissions made by the State Counsel, Mr Lemucha, a Senior State Advocate, in aggravating the sentence.

Before I consider what sentence to impose on the Convict herein I wish to comment briefly on the charge proffered by the State against the said Convict. For whatever reason the State have proffered on the Convict a charge of manslaughter contrary to Section 208 of the Penal Code and yet the facts obtaining herein clearly, in my considered view, disclose an offence of murder contrary to Section 209 of the Penal Code. All the elements required for the proof of a charge of murder under Section 209 of the Penal Code are available; the Convict admitted killing the deceased and even went further to admit killing her intentionally as per his Caution Statement admitted in Court as Exhibit Pl. But even if there had been no such admission, it is my considered view that there is sufficient ground upon which malice aforethought could be established as provided in Section 212(a) and (b) of the Penal Code.

"All in all, however, I must say I view homicide offences in grave light. Life is precious, and we all want to live. In Human Rights Law, and even in our Constitution, the right to life stands out above all other rights. It is for this reason that severe punishments are attached to the offences of Murder and Manslaughter. It thus disturbs me quite a bit when courts and/or society look down upon human life, and treat the taking of a life just like any ordinary crime," very persuasive and helpful in the passing of the sentence in this action. Doing the best as I can, I find a sentence of ten years imprisonment with hard labour appropriate for the Convict in the circumstances of this case.

Mr Kara, for the applicant depones in his affidavit that the applicant was convicted in September, 2008 by the Blantyre Magistrate's Court in Criminal Case Number 75 of 2008 of the offence of receiving stolen property contrary to Section 328(1) of the Penal Code]. The said Blantyre Magistrate's Court sentenced the applicant to 51/2 year's imprisonment with hard labour. The deponent further states that the applicant is desirous of appealing against his conviction and sentence and that he duly filed a Notice of Appeal to that effect within the time limited for filing a Notice of Appeal as required by the law through Messrs Denning Chambers. The deponent further states that when he was retained by the applicant to lodge an appeal on his behalf, the case record from the lower court could not be traced and that has been the position hitherto. The deponent therefore contends that since the missing of the court file is through no fault of his as the applicant has never been in control of the court file. The deponent further contends that the missing of the court record has actually hampered the applicant's right of appeal in serious degree, which has meant that the applicant has stayed in custody for over a year and has thus served close to half of his sentence, taking into account 1/3 remission of sentence on account of good behaviour.

column4: Section 355 (I) of the Criminal Procedure and Evidence Code
column7: To begin it is not in doubt that under with Section 355 (I) of the Criminal Procedure and Evidence Code, this court has jurisdiction to grant bail to an applicant or stay any sentence pending determination of his appeal. The said section provides:

To begin it is not in doubt that under with Section 355 (I) of the Criminal Procedure and Evidence Code, this court has jurisdiction to grant bail to an applicant or stay any sentence pending determination of his appeal. The said section provides:

355(1) "Subject to this Code, neither a notice of intention to appeal given under Section 349 nor a petition of appeal under Section 350 shall operate as a stay of execution of any sentence or order, but the subordinate which passed the sentence or made the order, or the High Court, may order that any such sentence or order be stayed pending the hearing of an appeal and if the appellant is in custody that he may be released on bail with or without sureties, pending such hearing. "

"

In determining whether or not to release the Applicant on bail as per his Application I remind myself of the fact that an accused person like the Applicant herein has a right under Section 42(2)(e) of the Constitution of the Republic of Malawi to be released from detention with or without bail unless the interests of justice require otherwise. And the burden as submitted by Counsel for the Applicant of showing by evidence that it would not be in the interest of justice that the accused person be granted bail lies on the State — See FADWECK MVAHE V THE REPUBLIC (supra) cited by Counsel for the Applicant.

INTRODUCTION The appellant is an Indian national. He was charged with Forging Immigration Documents contrary to section 35 of the Immigration Act and Entering Malawi Without a Visitors' Permit contrary to section 21(2)(a) as read with section 37(d) of the Immigration Act Cap 15:03 of the Laws of Malawi. He was convicted on pleas of guilty by the Ngerenge Third Grade Magistrates Court and then passed on to Karonga First Grade Magistrates Court for sentencing. On the first count he was sentenced to two and a half years IHL. On the second count the latter court refused to sentence. It thought that the appellant had been charged under the wrong section. It remedied the situation by dismissing the charge/conviction.

INTRODUCTION The appellant is an Indian national. He was charged with Forging Immigration Documents contrary to section 35 of the Immigration Act and Entering Malawi Without a Visitors' Permit contrary to section 21(2)(a) as read with section 37(d) of the Immigration Act Cap 15:03 of the Laws of Malawi. He was convicted on pleas of guilty by the Ngerenge Third Grade Magistrates Court and then passed on to Karonga First Grade Magistrates Court for sentencing. On the first count he was sentenced to two and a half years IHL. On the second count the latter court refused to sentence. It thought that the appellant had been charged under the wrong section. It remedied the situation by dismissing the charge/conviction.

The Discharge The magistrate at Karonga purported to dismiss the conviction on the second charge for having been brought under the wrong section. We think we should say our tuppence worth about it. While the latter trial court was most likely correct in observing that the charging section was wrong it erred in dismissing the conviction on the second count. It purported to act as if it was a reviewing or appellate court in relation to the Ngerenge court which is not as a matter of fact and law the case. Having noted the error of law the said court should have forwarded the case to this court or indeed that of the Chief Magistrate with a suggestion that the matter be reviewed to establish the propriety of the manner in which the Ngerenge court had dealt with the matter. Put simply the Karonga Court acted without jurisdiction.

I have considered the arguments for and against the I have also considered the reasons given by Twea J (as the then was) in refusing to grant bail to the Accused on two separate occasions and while agreeing with Counsel for the Accused that the Accused has a Constitutional right to be tried within a reasonable time under Section 42(2) (f) of the Constitution of the Republic of Malawi sight must not be lost of the principles upon which the courts act in granting or refusing to grant bail which are contained in the Bail (Guidelines) Act, 2000. It has been emphasised by these courts that the primary consideration is whether the Accused if released on bail shall avail himself/herself for trial and whether his/ her release or denial of bail will be in the interests of justice. The other considerations to be taken into account by the court are the nature and the seriousness of the offence, the strength of the evidence against the Accused, the possibility of the accused tampering with evidence or witnesses if released on bail etc. Twea J (as the then was) in his Ruling of the 11th March 2008 came to the conclusion that the offence the Accused is alleged to have committed is a serous one and that the evidence against her is strong. He thus concluded that it would not serve the interests of justice to release the Accused on bail in those circumstances.

column4: section 187 (1) Criminal Procedure and Evidence Code
column7: Law and Facts For the state to secure a conviction they must prove not only that a crime was committed, but that it was committed by the Appellant. He who alleges must prove. The starting point is section 187 (1) Criminal Procedure and Evidence Code.

The Offences. The offence of theft by servant has its own elements. Section 286 Penal Code provides: If the offender is a clerk or servant and the thing stolen is the property of his employer, or came into the possession of the offender on account of his employer, he sha// be /iab/e to imprisonment for fourteen years.

The State must prove that the accused was employed by the complainant at the material time and that while in employment he stole property belonging to the employer or stole property which was in his possession on account of employment. On the second part under section 278 Penal Code, the general elements of the offence of theft must be satisfied.

I have no doubt, in my mind, that the Applicants in this case as Accused persons have under Section 42 (2) (e) of the Constitutional of the Republic of Malawi a right to be released from their detention, with or without bail unless the interests of justice require otherwise. It is also settled that if the State asserts that it would not be in the interests of justice that the accused person be granted bail then the State must give reasons in support of the assertion-see: the Malawi Supreme Court of Appeal decision in the cases of FADWECK MVAHE V THE REPUBLIC MSCA Criminal Appeal No. 25 of 2005, RICHARD CHIGEZA V THE REPUBLIC MSCA Criminal Appeal No. 26 of 2005 and ROY MANGAME V THE REPUBLIC MSCA Criminal Appeal No. 27 of 2005 (unreported) at page

This being the direction to the Courts hearing bail applications, I will thus give no due regard to the submission made by Defence Counsel that the State can hardly sustain a charge of murder because the circumstances are very clear in that they disclose an offence of manslaughter. Whether or not the State can sustain a charge of murder against the Applicants in this case is in my ruling immaterial. I have however, given due regard to the concern by the State that murder being a serious offence it does encounter numerous problems in tracing homicide suspects despite making an undertaking to appear at trial and that it was for this reason that they prayed that bail should be granted on stiff conditions as would ensure the availability of the Applicants at the trial. SENTENCE The Accused has been found guilty on his own plea and he has been convicted accordingly. The offence of which he was charged is murder contrary to section 209 of the Penal Code. Murder is causing death of another with malice aforethought and by unlawful act. The maximum sentence of this offence is death. The maximum punishment only goes to show how seriously society views this offence. Infact the sentence of death was mandatory for every proven case of murder before the cases of Two Boy Jacob, Kafantayeni vs Republic, Evance Namizinga and Phiri vs Republic and the case of Sadik John AKM John Biziwiki Kasawala v Republic which cases were decided by the Supreme Court of Appeal and therefore endorsed the argument that death sentence violates S19(1)(2) and S42(2) of the Constitution.

BACKGROUND The accused was charged together with one Matembo Munthali of the offence of Being Found in Possession of Property Reasonably Suspected of Having Been Stolen or Unlawfully Obtained contrary to section 329 of the Penal Code. After a full trial he was convicted and fined K5000.00 in default 12months IHL. The co- accused was acquitted. The matter was urgently set down to consider the propriety of the conviction.

THE CONVICTION Our understanding of the conviction is that the court below was convinced beyond doubt that the convict was inter alia found in possession of ten coupons and secondly that the said court found nothing wrong with section 329 abovementioned generally and applied to this our case. It is those very issues that we address in this opinion.

evidence that the convict was not present when Matembo's house was being searched in the same way that Matembo was absent. Having excluded the results of such search against Matembo we would have thought the same should have been done in respect of the convict. But that notwithstanding we think with the greatest respect that the court below got the wrong end of the law relating to possession in so far as it applied to this our case. The commonly understood view of possession is that one should be in physical possession of the item(s) in issue. In the alternative the items in issue should be at a place over which the accused has control. The seven coupons were found at Matembo's house. This is a house occupied by more than one person at any given time. One would think that the court below should have acted with caution before it concluded that the coupons belonged to this or that particular occupant of the house. But perhaps more importantly it is important to note that the convict never actually lived in that house. Matembo and some of the witnesses did. If anything the convict was at most a regular visitor to the house. Did that warrant the court below to find that the seven coupons were the convict's? The answer has to be in the negative. As we understood its thinking the court below felt that because the ten coupons in issue clearly came form one book, because they clearly were (in its view) stolen and because the convict had been found with the other three then the conclusion must be that he knew something about all of them; that he must be said to be or have been in possession of all ten of them. In so far as the seven were concerned the court below fell into error. Like we have said above, and like the said court itself said in respect of Matembo, the search was an illegal one. Its result could not therefore be allowed in evidence. In much the same way that they were excluded in respect of Matembo we think they should have been excluded against the convict. To the extent therefore that the court below based its decision on the fruits of the search such a decision cannot stand. We should say at this point however that the matter of illegal searches goes beyond mere illegality. In today's constitututiinoal dispensation it is a matter of human rights, respect for the law and the defense of the constitution. See the right to privacy as provided for in section 21 of the Constitution. Further and again as we say above, it is obvious that the convict cannot be said to have had, at the material time, exclusive control over the room in which the coupons were found. At law it cannot be said therefore that he had possession of the coupons seeing as they were in Matembo's house. They could have been Matembo's. They could have been the property of any one of the persons who lived in that house. Our conclusion therefore has to be that as a matter of fact the court below erred in concluding that the seven coupons found in Matembo's house belonged to or were in the possession of the convict. Regarding the three coupons found with Malange we are prepared to find that they were at all material times in possession of the convict. After all despite the fact that Malange had physical possession of them it was at all times subject to the superior property rights and sanction of the convict. We shall therefore

Section 329 offences We asked the State whether in view of the recent decision of Jumbe and Mvula v R Constitutional Case Number 1 of 2005 it is still proper to charge persons with offences under section 329 abovementioned. Whether or not section 329 was constitutional or not. Its view was that the section is perfectly constitutional. That all it requires from a suspect found with property reasonably suspected of having been stolen or unlawfully obtained is an explanation on a balance of probabilities that such is not in fact the case. That the burden it places on the accused is nothing more than an evidential burden. We differed with the State. As we understand the law the Constitution grants one the right to remain silent or to speak in one's defense. It also gives one the right to refuse to give a statement the effect of which will be to incriminate oneself. See section 42 of the Constitution. Those rights are available without discrimination to all accused persons. A section 329 suspect on the other hand does not have such choice. Once the powers that be make their mind that she must have stolen or illegally obtained whatever property he has in his possession it behoves her to explain on the pain of a conviction that he has innocent possession of such property. That in my view goes beyond mere evidential burden. That goes into the realm of coercion. Whatever explanation the accused gives therefore is one that is extorted from him for fear of being found guilty of an offence under section 329 of the Penal Code. That sounds to us like discrimination. In other words that section 329 has in practice the effect of treating differently identically placed suspects. Whereas others are allowed to keep quite others are coerced to speak. But perhaps more than that we have no doubt that the explanation sought from the accused is in fact a disguised way of asking the accused to prove himself innocent. So that if one is less than adept at doing so he might be found guilty irrespective of the fact that he might actually be in innocent possession of the property in issue That is unconstitutional. See the case of Jumbe and Mvula referred to above. On a different note we always like to think this kind of penal provision is a lazy way of fighting and/ or dealing with crime. Rather than try and find out whether or not the suspect is in innocent possession they dare the suspect to prove herself innocent. That is not how it should be. It is for the law enforcement agencies to prove that a suspect is in illegal possession of property either because they have stolen the same or because of some other illegality. And if the suspect has stolen the property the correct way forward is not to proceed under section 329 but to charge the suspect with theft and prove it. It is not to allow them to get some conviction of the suspect through the backdoor when they can not get one through the front door by allowing them to bring forward a section 329 prosecution in the hope that the suspect will fail to explain herself.
