Section 329 offences We asked the State whether in view of the recent decision of Jumbe and Mvula v R Constitutional Case Number 1 of 2005 it is still proper to charge persons with offences under section 329 abovementioned. Whether or not section 329 was constitutional or not. Its view was that the section is perfectly constitutional. That all it requires from a suspect found with property reasonably suspected of having been stolen or unlawfully obtained is an explanation on a balance of probabilities that such is not in fact the case. That the burden it places on the accused is nothing more than an evidential burden. We differed with the State. As we understand the law the Constitution grants one the right to remain silent or to speak in one's defense. It also gives one the right to refuse to give a statement the effect of which will be to incriminate oneself. See section 42 of the Constitution. Those rights are available without discrimination to all accused persons. A section 329 suspect on the other hand does not have such choice. Once the powers that be make their mind that she must have stolen or illegally obtained whatever property he has in his possession it behoves her to explain on the pain of a conviction that he has innocent possession of such property. That in my view goes beyond mere evidential burden. That goes into the realm of coercion. Whatever explanation the accused gives therefore is one that is extorted from him for fear of being found guilty of an offence under section 329 of the Penal Code. That sounds to us like discrimination. In other words that section 329 has in practice the effect of treating differently identically placed suspects. Whereas others are allowed to keep quite others are coerced to speak. But perhaps more than that we have no doubt that the explanation sought from the accused is in fact a disguised way of asking the accused to prove himself innocent. So that if one is less than adept at doing so he might be found guilty irrespective of the fact that he might actually be in innocent possession of the property in issue That is unconstitutional. See the case of Jumbe and Mvula referred to above. On a different note we always like to think this kind of penal provision is a lazy way of fighting and/ or dealing with crime. Rather than try and find out whether or not the suspect is in innocent possession they dare the suspect to prove herself innocent. That is not how it should be. It is for the law enforcement agencies to prove that a suspect is in illegal possession of property either because they have stolen the same or because of some other illegality. And if the suspect has stolen the property the correct way forward is not to proceed under section 329 but to charge the suspect with theft and prove it. It is not to allow them to get some conviction of the suspect through the backdoor when they can not get one through the front door by allowing them to bring forward a section 329 prosecution in the hope that the suspect will fail to explain herself. The State did

say that looking at the nature of property in issue herein, fertilizer coupons, it was clear that they had been stolen. Our response is that if it is that clear then it is equally clear that it behove the prosecution to allege and prove a charge of theft against the convict. Not for the accused to prove that he is not guilty of theft or some other unspecified offence(s). Our view has to be that therefore even if the convict were found in possession of three coupons a charge under section 329 cannot stand for being unconstitutional. In case some might be wondering whether this court has the mandate to make such pronouncements in view of recent amendments to the Courts Act that seem to restrict constitutional pronouncements to the Constitutional Court, our view has always been that section 108 of our Constitution is crystal clear about the jurisdiction of the High Court which this court is. Reading that section with section 103(3) of the constitution means, in our view, that even the so called Constitutional Court is no more than a division of the High Court. What in less formal circumstances we refer to as a gentlemen's arrangement to lend some, perhaps unnecessary weight, to the High Court. This court sitting in whatever capacity can and does make pronouncements having a bearing on the Constitution. The one we made earlier herein is one such pronouncement.

The convict together with his coaccused made several applications for bail in the trial court. They were refused. The thinking of the trial court from what we could gather from its record was that the convict and his friend had shown no exceptional circumstances on the basis of which bail could be granted. Further that since the police were still carrying on with their investigations it was proper that bail be declined. The trial court fell into error. It emanates from treating bail as a right which it is not. Rather bail as used in the Constitution refers to the condition(s) on which one is released. Because bail was treated as a right the trial court thought, correctly maybe, that every right is limitable. The correct way to approach a request for bail when used to mean a release from detention pending a hearing of one's case in our view is to treat, as does the Constitution in section 18, liberty as a right so that when one is incarcerated that is tantamount to a limitation by the arresting authority, in this case the State, of such right. And like in all cases of limitations it is then the duty of the one limiting the liberty to show, on a balance of probabilities, that such limitation is in accordance with section 44(2) of the Constitution. Applied to this case once the convict and his coaccused were brought into court on remand it would have been the duty of the State to show why they should not be released with or without bail and NOT for the convict to show exceptional circumstances why he should be released from custody with or without bail. This thinking has just been endorsed by the Malawi Supreme Court of Appeal in the cases of Fadweck Mvahe v R MSCA No. 25 of 2005 and Roy

It is clear from both the affidavits filed in this action and the submissions by both Counsel that a similar Motion to the present was heard by and is pending the determination of my sister Judge Mrs Kamanga in the High Court of Malawi, Lilongwe District Registry. While the ruling is still pending as aforesaid, the Accused person has decided to take out this Motion in the belief that this Court would deliver its ruling with due dispatch. The matter has given me some anxious moments due to the fact that the two Courts with the same jurisdiction have been moved to make a decision on the same or similar applications. What would be the effect of the rulings to be delivered by the two Courts, should the same be divergent with each other in conclusions? I believe that such a scenario can best be avoided by this Court not proceeding to make any determination on the present Motion. In this regard I wish to agree with State Counsel that the present Motion is clearly an abuse of the process of the Court. This Court has power to prevent the improper use of its machinery by say, dismissing or striking out the claim. Further, I find it also administratively awkward for the Accused person herein to invite this Court, sitting at Blantyre and about 300km or so away, to exercise the Court's powers under Section 26(1) of the Courts Act in respect of proceedings taking place in a Chief Resident Magistrate's Court sitting at Lilongwe when there is another Court with the same jurisdiction as this Court sitting just a few metres away from the said Magistrate's Court. It is my considered view that much as it may be desirable in the interest justice so to do, the exercise of such powers by this Court would, no doubt, be impinging on the jurisdiction and integrity of the High Court, Lilongwe District Registry, as alluded to by Counsel for the State. When dealing with a case of defilement a court should warn itself of the dangers of convicting the accused in the absence of corroboration. As a general rule unsworn evidence of one child can not corroborate the unsworn evidence of another child. Corroboration in sexual offences though not a matter of law is by legal tradition a matter of practice.

The convicts are all of Somali extraction. They were charged in the court below with Illegal Entry into Malawi under section 21(1)(a) as read with section 37(d) of the Immigration Act Cap 15:03 of the Laws of Malawi. They were convicted on pleas of guilty. When it came to sentencing the prosecutor drew the attention of the court to the fact that the convicts had barely two weeks before been convicted before the Third Grade Magistrates Court Ngerenge which had inter alia ordered for their deportation. With full knowledge of the previous conviction the court below ordered by way of sentence that the convicts be sent by the Malawi Immigration authorities to Dzaleka Refugee Camp where they would be processed as refugees. This was in lieu of being sent to prison or being deported. The prosecutorial services were none too pleased about this and asked that this matter be reviewed. It is therefore in our review capacity that we find ourselves presiding over this matter.

I remind myself of the fact that it is the Constitutional right under Section 42(2)(E) of the Constitution of the Republic of Malawi of an accused person to be released from detention with or without bail unless the interests of justice require otherwise. As per the wording of the provision giving the right to bail Courts have held that such a right is not absolute but is subject to the interests of justice. See: Director of Public Prosecutions v Lunguzi [1995] 2 MLR 632 at pp 635 and 635. And the burden of showing that it would not be in the interest of justice that the accused person be granted bail lies on the State See: FADWECK MVAHE V THE REPUBLIC MSCA Criminal Appeal No. 25 of 2005.

I have given the matter my considered thought and having regard to the fact that trial has already commenced in the action with two witnesses having already testified on behalf of the State it would give rise to unnecessary delays to bring the Applicants to attend trial if they are released on bail and the case is set down for continued hearing soon. Further, releasing an accused person in a case where part of the evidence has already been given can at times prove tricky more especially when the evidence given tends to implicate the accused person in the commission of the crime. For these reasons I would think that releasing the Applicants on bail at this stage may prejudice the interests of justice which need to be safeguarded at all material times and are in fact provided for by Section 42(2)(e) of the said Constitution. As a matter of fact I think it would have been more expedient had this Application been made to the Judge at the trial of the case. In the circumstances I would decline to order the release of the Applicants on bail as per their However, in order to ensure that the continuation of the hearing of the case does not delay unduly I would grant the prayer by the State and order that the Registrar of this Court should set the case down for continued hearing by the 14th day of January 2011. Should the trial of the case fail to resume by that date then let the Applicants be at liberty to re-apply for trial to this Court.

On the 17th day of December, 2009 1 proceeded to hear Counsel for the parties on the erroneous belief that the Application before me was an ordinary application for bail. fact this is how Counsel addressed me, they didi not address me as if they were addressing me on an appeal. After hearing Cousel for the parties I reserved my Ruling to a date to be fixed. When the time for the preparation of the Ruling came up I realised that I should not have wasted my time in hearing Counsel in the matter on the grounds that the refusal of bail by a Magistrate is not a matter which is a subject of appeal. See Tembo and Others v Reppublic [1995] IMLR 308 per It is to be appreciated that a party aggrieved with the decision of a subordinate court refusing him bail in proceedings pending before that court ought to proceed under Section 118 (5) of the Criminal Procedure and Evidence Code which provides as follows:- "No application for a direction that any person in custody pending proceedings in asubordinate court be released on bail shall be entertained by the High Court unless such subordinate court has first refused to direct such release. '

column4: Section 118 (5) of the Criminal Procedure and Evidence Code
column7: On the 17th day of December, 2009 1 proceeded to hear Counsel for the parties on the erroneous belief that the Application before me was an ordinary application for bail. fact this is how Counsel addressed me, they didi not address me as if they were addressing me on an appeal. After hearing Cousel for the parties I reserved my Ruling to a date to be fixed. When the time for the preparation of the Ruling came up I realised that I should not have wasted my time in hearing Counsel in the matter on the grounds that the refusal of bail by a Magistrate is not a matter which is a subject of appeal. See Tembo and Others v Reppublic [1995] IMLR 308 per It is to be appreciated that a party aggrieved with the decision of a subordinate court refusing him bail in proceedings pending before that court ought to proceed under Section 118 (5) of the Criminal Procedure and Evidence Code which provides as follows:- "No application for a direction that any person in custody pending proceedings in asubordinate court be released on bail shall be entertained by the High Court unless such subordinate court has first refused to direct such release. '

The foregoing provision, in my view, gives an automatic right to a party to make an application for the grant of bail to the High Court if such a grant has been refused by the subordinate court. It is to be appreciated further, that since the matter is at this stage still interlocutory the right of appeal does not accrue. For these reasons I therefore, dismiss the Appeal summarily under Section 351 (1) of the Criminal Procedure and Endence Code.

column4: Section 15 of the Criminal Procedure and Evidence Code
column7: matter has so far been registered in the High Court both as a Confirmation Case and as an Appeal Case. Procedurally and legally, this is quite acceptable. Under Section 15 of the Criminal Procedure and Evidence Code (cap 8-01) of the Laws of Malawi (hereinafter referred to as the CP&EC) most Criminal cases that are decided in Magistrates' Courts must routinely be referred to the High Court for confirmation purposes. Among cases that have to be so referred to the High Court, fall those where actual custodial imprisonment has been meted out on a first offender, where the penalty of a fine going beyond a fixed minimum threshold has been imposed, where regardless of whether an Accused is a first or a repeat offender, and depending on the level of Magistrate dealing with the case, a fixed length of imprisonment has been exceeded for that Grade of Magistrate. The present case, when it was in the Court below, involved a total of five Accused persons. Although I notice that the lower Court virtually converted all the imprisonment sentences it had meted out on the five Convicts to Suspended Sentences, I also notice that for most of those sentences it so suspended them on condition that the Convicts pay reasonably hefty fines in lieu, from which it further made various Compensation Orders for the concerned Complainants. On account of some of these punishments having qualified the case herein for a Section 15(1 to (d) of the CP&EC review, of necessity therefore, this case was bound to be automatically referred for mandatory review by the High Court soon the lower Court was through with it.

As a Confirmation Case, this case was thus registered as Confirmation Case No. 524 of 2009 when it so reached the High Court. Having been so registered, I further notice that in due time, i.e. on 13th July, 2009, it was perused by a Review Judge in Chambers, who directed it to be set down for a hearing in Open Court as follows: "Set down to consider the propriety of the sentences- are they custodial sentences, fines or fines in default? The Magistrate seems confused. " Opportunity for the directed confirmation hearing to take place, it appears, never really came up. This is because as the lower Court was preparing to refer the matter to the High Court for review, within a fortnight or thereabouts of the lower Court pronouncing its sentences in the matter on 6th June, 2009, one of the Accused persons in the case, i.e. the first in the set of the five Accused, on 23rd June, 2009, though M/S Winlaw & Ndau, lodged an appeal against both the convictions he got on three Counts in the matter, and against the sentences that were imposed on him. As a result of this development, the same case, with him alone as Appellant, and with the Republic as Respondent in the Appeal, was opened. His said appeal ended up being registered as Criminal Appeal No. 9 of 2009. I further notice that a week later, on 30th June, 2009, through M/S Ralph and Arnold Associates, a second Notice of Appeal, reflecting all five Accused Persons as appealing against the whole judgment in the case, was filed. The Appeal record, however, continued to reflect only the person who had been first Accused in the Court below as the sole Appellant in the case. M/s Ral h and Arnold Associates eventually by Notice of Appointment dated and filed on 16tl November, 2009, placed themselves on record as Legal Practitioners for this sole Appellant. In the absence of M/S Ralph and Arnold Associates hereafter making any further reference to the joint Notice of Appeal they had filed for five Accused Persons, except in respect of the single Appellant they now represent, and in the further absence of them taking steps to assume any Legal

Representation for the five Accused they issued the Notice of Appeal for, save for the present Appellant, and no Skeleton Arguments having been filed personally by any of the remaining four Accused in that group, or by any other Legal House on their behalf, and additionally it being the case that generally those four accused have neither attended the Appeal Proceedings nor played any other role in it, I take it that such appeal by the four as might have been created by the citation of their names in the Notice of Appeal of 30th June, 2009, has been effectively abandoned.

A look at Section 362(4) of the CP&EC will show that where Criminal Proceedings arising from a Subordinate Court have not been reviewed in Open Court at the High Court, with opportunity to be heard duly extended to the Accused, there can be no bar to an appeal being taken out by the concerned Accused against either conviction or sentence. In the instant case, where at the time the Appellant lodged his Appeal the matter was probably still in the course of being referred to the High Court for confirmation under Section 15 of the CP &EC, there was, therefore, clearly no barrier against him appealing, as he did, against his said convictions and sentences. The only effect, however, of the Appeal he so took out, is that it removed him out of the group of co-Accused Persons that were then jointly awaiting the dispatch of their case file for Confirmation Proceedings in the High Court. This is in the sense that since my hearing of his Appeal, and only subject to such further rights of appeal as the parties might wish to exercise by taking this matter further to the Supreme Court of Appeal once I am done with it, the Judgment I am now pronouncing will result in a determination of the case in so far as it relates to him with finality. The Confirmation Proceedings that are yet to be held for the rest of the Accused persons, who did not pursue the Appeal M/S Ralph and Arnold Associates purported to file on their behalf, will accordingly no longer apply to

I notice that the case, from then on, proceeded as a single case, under banner of Criminal Case Number 36 of 2008. The total number of Counts in the said consolidated Charge Sheet came to six for the whole group of five Accused persons, but the Appellant was only cited in three out of those Counts. In the first Count he was charged with the offence of Grievous Harm contrary to Section 238 of the Penal Code (cap 7:01) of the Laws of Malawi. The particulars of this Count were to the effect that on 22nd March, 2008 at Selemani Village in Machinga District he unlawfully did grievous harm to Henderson Biston Muleme. In the second Count the Appellant was charged with Common Assault contrary to Section 253 of the same Code, the allegation here being that at the same time and place as stated in the first Count he unlawfully assaulted Ninety Banda. In the sixth Count the Appellant faced a Charge of Malicious Damage under Section 344 of the same Code, where the particulars averred were to the effect, likewise, that at the same time and place as cited in the first Count, he willfully and unlawfully damaged a Mazda Saloon motor vehicle registered number BH 9902, property of Henderson Biston Muleme.

After so hearing the case in full, the Court below on 9th May, 2009 delivered its Judgment in the case, in which it convicted the Appellant on all the three Counts he had been charged with. A month passed, and on 6th June, 2009 the Court sentenced the Appellant as follows: "After carefully considering all factors both in mitigation and aggravation and on the basis of the discretion before me, I sentence you Rev. Wilson Ndomondo to twelve (12) months imprisonment with hard labour for the offence of Causing Grievous Harm C/S 238 of the penal Code. I also sentence you Rev. Wilson Ndomondo to twelve (12) months imprisonment with hard labour for the offence of Malicious Damage C/S 344 of the Penal [Code]. I also sentence you Rev Wilson Ndomondo to six (6) months imprisonment with hard labour for the offence of Common Assault C/S 253 of the Penal Code. " The Court then immediately proceeded to suspend the sentence it had imposed for the Grievous harm Count on condition that the Appellant pays a fine of KI 50,000.00 of which it ordered KI 35,000.00 to be paid to Mr Muleme as exemplary damages. It also immediately suspended the operation of the imprisonment it had imposed for the offence of Malicious Damage on condition that the Appellant pays a fine of out of which K245,000.00 was ordered to be paid to Mr Muleme as exemplary damages. The lower Court also suspended the sentence it had imposed for Common Assault for a period of 12 months, but without attaching any condition to the said suspension of sentence.

Both Judgment and Sentence having been pronounced as above disclosed, as I have earlier on indicated, by the time the month of June, 2009 was ending the Appellant had two Notices of Appeal to his credit against his Convictions and Sentences, from two Legal Houses. Considering also, as pointed out earlier, that one such Notice was not even followed up with a Notice of Appointment in respect of the Legal Practitioners that filed it, in this Appeal, therefore, the Court has proceeded on the basis of the Notice of Appeal that was filed by M/S Ralph and Arnold Associates, who are the only Lawyers on record for the Appellant. While the said Notice of Appeal carried a set of six Grounds of Appeal, that seek two reliefs, i.e. (i) the quashing of the Convictions the Appellant got, and (ii) the consequent setting aside of the sentences that accompanied the convictions, in arguing the Appeal, the Appellant condensed all those Grounds of Appeal into two only. The two questions that now sum up all of the Appellant's Grounds of Appeal are (a) whether at the trial the Prosecution proved beyond reasonable doubt that the Appellant did commit the offences he was convicted of, and (b) whether the Prosecution in fact proved beyond reasonable doubt that in fact the offences charged were committed.

The two questions that now sum up all of the Appellant's Grounds of Appeal are (a) whether at the trial the Prosecution proved beyond reasonable doubt that the Appellant did commit the offences he was convicted of, and (b) whether the Prosecution in fact proved beyond reasonable doubt that in fact the offences charged were committed.

I need also to mention here and now that while reasonable time was devoted by the parties to arguing the Ground of Appeal concerning whether the offences involving personal injury (i.e. Assault and Grievous Harm) were actually proved in light of the manner Medical Reports in their respect were tendered in the Court below, and on account of the question whether the said Medical Reports were capable of proving Grievous Harm as defined in Section 4 of the Penal Code, I will only address that Ground, if the need to do so remains outstanding, towards the end of my Judgment. It dawns on me at the moment that in a scenario where the first question posed for my consideration relates to a wider concern on the Appellant's part i.e the question whether at all the Prosecution did satisfactorily prove both his presence at the scene of crime, and his involvement in the commission of the crimes he was convicted of ,questions such as whether the evidence presented established Grievous Harm as legally understood are secondary, and they only become relevant depending on how the question whether there is a connection between the offence(s) and the alleged perpetrator of the same is resolved. To in advance, therefore, dwell on questions such as whether the Medical Reports on record were properly tendered, and what probative value their contents had, before the question whether the Prosecution sufficiently connected the Appellant to the crimes he is complaining he has been wrongly convicted of is resolved, could easily be the equivalent of placing the cart before the horse. My initial focus in dealing with this Appeal, therefore, will be on the Grounds of Appeal that are summed up in the question whether the Prosecution in this case did prove, to the requisite legal standard, the fact that the Appellant committed the three offences he was convicted of.

column4: Section 42 of the Constitution of Malawi
column7: The inference the lower Court so drew from the prima facie case test it quoted from the Chidzero case is, from a Criminal Procedure point of view, far from correct. In fact, I feel obliged to say, it is also a potentially dangerous view for a Court to hold vis-å-vis the proper exercise of the right to fair trial, which embodies the right to silence, which by virtue of Section 42 of the Constitution of Malawi, Accused persons ought to enjoy without restraint in every Court of Law. Carried to extremity, its meaning would be that once an Accused has been found with a case to answer, he/she cannot safely exercise his/her right to silence without risking a conviction, because, according to the understanding of the Court below as depicted in its inference herein, a Court is entitled to assume that it can convict an Accused purely on basis of its having earlier found a prima facie case against him or her, unless, as that Court seems to suggest, he/she fights that finding adequately. Really, if the position of the Law were as so surmised by the lower

With the greatest respect to the learned Court, its said expectations from the Appellant when he embarked on his defence were tantamount to saddling him with a burden of proof the Law does not place on shoulders of an Accused person in a Criminal Case involving most Defences, including that of an alibi. The constant position of the Law on Criminal Cases in general, I must reiterate, is (i) that the Accused is presumed innocent until proved guilty, (ii) that proof of guilt is the duty of the accuser, and that the degree of proof must reach highly demanding levels far beyond just hanging around preponderances of probability, and (iii) that the Accused does not, in the least, shoulder any obligation to prove his innocence. Statements in a Judgment, therefore, tending to the effect that once a Court has put an Accused on his defence, then the onus is on him or her to fight through adequate explanation against the trend of events so as to turn them from a possible conviction to an acquittal, as the lower Court is on record to have made in this case, inherently suggest that to the extent it championed that view, the lower Court openly demonstrated that contrary to the above established legal principles it was expecting the Appellant to prove himself innocent, and that therefore merely raising a reasonable doubt about his guilt was not going to help him at all, as it was definitely not going to meet with the Court's expectations.

that a primafacie ruling has only got a limited role to play in Criminal proceedings, and that that role ends the moment it is delivered. With this misunderstanding, as I have also shown, the lower Court infused the said ruling into its Judgment, and throughout used it as a barometer for measuring the Appellant's guilt. In the circumstances, I find the lower Court's verdicts of guilt and its convictions of the Appellant on al three Counts it tried him on quite unsafe, as I am not convinced that the lower Court could have claimed that it was satisfied beyond reasonable doubt about the guilt of the Appellant had it applied correct legal principles in its attitude towards the evidence before it and in its compilation of the Judgment herein. In the result, I quash all the three convictions that were entered against the Appellant, namely of Grievous Harm of Henderson Biston Muleme under Section 238 of the Penal Code, of Common Assault of Ninety Banda under Section 253 of the Penal Code, and of Malicious Damage of Henderson Biston Muleme's motor vehicle under Section 344 of the Penal Code. At the same time, and in consequence of the quashing of the convictions herein, I set aside all the three sentences that the lower Court meted out on the Appellant. I further order that if the fines, including their built-in exemplary damages, the lower Court imposed on him as a condition for avoiding immediate custodial imprisonment were paid, they should be refunded to the Appellant within 30 days hereof.
